body:
RomTelecom, the biggest fixed telephony operator in Romania, might go through important changes in the next period, at the end of years-long process of complicate privatization process. 

An expected listing on the stock exchange will be prepared by a possible merging between RomTelecom and Cosmote Romania, the local subsidiary of the Hellenic Telecommunications Organizations, the largest telecommunications provider in Greece and one of the leading telecom groups in Southeastern Europe. The merging will diminish the Romanian’s state share participation in the company. The share of the Romanian state in the company is currently of 45.99%, with OTE 54.01% shareholder.

But until the final deal will be signed, there are a couple of conditions waiting to be fulfilled. According to the Telecommunication minister, Valerian Vreme, quoted by Ziarul Financiar, Romania would not sell its stake to OTE if the price offered is much less than 1 billion euros (USD1.37 billion). In November 2010, Romania unveiled plans to dispose of the stake to OTE, which already controls the Romanian telecommunications operator. In December last year, OTE’s chief, Michael Tsamaz, said his company will take three more months to decide whether to take full control of Romtelecom, Reuters reported.  

According to news agency Mediafax, Vreme has already met with representatives of several investment banks, including Citibank, Goldman Sachs and Rothschild, in preparation for the possible stock market listing.

In January 2011, RomTelecom shareholders approved the distribution of dividends from the net profit of the company from 2006 and 2007 worth 94.75 million euro - http://english.hotnews.ro/stiri-top_news-8257560-romanian-state-cash-dividends-worth-43-5-million-euro-from-romtelecoms-profits-for-2006-and-2007.htm

Cosmote Romania is the third largest mobile company in Romania, after Orange and Vodafone.  RomTelecom, founded in 1930,  is one of the leading providers of pay-TV services in the country and benefits of an important network and infrastructure in the country - http://www.telecompaper.com/news/romtelecom-orange-vodafone-win-contracts-from-govt. Until January 2003, the company had the monopoly of fixed telephony services. Recently, Vodafone and Orange Romania were fined by the Romania’s Competition Council by 63.1 million euro for abuse of dominant position, following an investigation filled in 2006, but the companies are expected to challenge the ruling in court - http://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20110215/tc_afp/romaniafrancebritaintelecomcompetition.

The Romanian telecommunication market was fully liberalized in 2003, following the negotiations for the European Union. The share of 35% was sold to OTE in 1998 and the transaction was for a long time suspiciously scrutinized as corrupt, but no accusations were proved by now. Since then, OTE acquired additional 18%.
